Description: Service 1: Prepare Scope of work & Implement Plan and Deliverables
1.1 Feature Overview
1.2 Implementation Plan
1.3 Initial Task List
Service 2: Install and configure all core components required for a highly available Zabbix monitoring.
2.1: Install Zabbix Monitoring Cluster
2.1.1: Install and configure Zabbix Server (2 Nodes - Active/Standby)
2.1.2: Install and configure Zabbix Web UI via NGINX (2 Nodes)
2.1.3: Configure High-Availability Load Balancer for Web UI (via HAProxy & keepalived)
2.2: Deploy Zabbix Proxies and Database
2.2.1: Install and configure Zabbix Proxy with MariaDB (24 Nodes)
2.2.2: Install and configure PostgreSQL Cluster (3 Nodes) with TimescaleDB extension
2.2.3: Validate TimescaleDB performance and compression features
2.2.4: Connect Zabbix Server to PostgreSQL cluster
2.3: Deploy HA Components
2.3.1: Install HAProxy (2 Nodes)
2.3.2: Configure keepalived for virtual IP (VIP) management
2.3.3: Load balancing configuration for Web UI PostgreSQL Redis
2.4: Install and Configure Redis
2.4.1: Install Redis Cluster for Zabbix caching
2.4.2: Configure Zabbix to use Redis for value caching
2.4.3: Secure Redis access and define data retention policy
2.5: Install and Configure Elasticsearch
2.5.1: Deploy Elasticsearch Cluster (3 Nodes) for log storage
2.5.2: Configure Zabbix to send history logs to Elasticsearch
2.5.3: Install GitLab CE
2.5.4: Configure GitLab runners repos and access control
2.6: Install and Configure Grafana
2.6.1: Install Grafana Server
2.6.2: Configure data sources (Zabbix PostgreSQL ElasticSearch
2.6.3: Create basic dashboard templates for monitoring overview
2.6.4: Set up authentication and role-based access
Service 3: Automated Device Data Integration (Script-Based Data Collection) (Briefly Performance for 1st Release)
3.1: Build Initial Data Collection Script  for MPLS Devices
3.1.1: Read data from Netka via DB Connect
3.1.2: Read data from DTWH via DB/API
3.1.3: Cleanse and normalize MPLS device data
3.1.4: Insert into Zabbix DB
3.1.5: Export From Zabbix to Excel and verify with UIH
3.2: Build Initial Data Collection Script for Network & Access Switches
3.2.1: Read data from NCE (API)
3.2.2: Read data from E-Sight (API)
3.2.3: Read data from DTWH (DB/API)
3.2.4: Cleanse and merge switch data
3.2.5: Insert into Zabbix DB
3.2.6: Export to Excel and verify with UIH
3.3: Build Initial Data Collection Script for CPE Routers and WiFi APs
3.3.1: Read data from MRS (DB)
3.3.2: Read data from Controller (API)
3.3.3: Read data from DTWH (DB/API)
3.3.4: Cleanse router and WiFi data
3.3.5: Insert into Zabbix DB
3.3.6: Export to Excel and verify with UIH
3.4: Build Initial Data Collection Script for SDWAN/Firewall Devices
3.4.1: Read data from Controller 3 Node (API)
3.4.2: Cleanse firewall and SDWAN data
3.4.3: Insert into Zabbix DB
3.4.4: Export to Excel and verify with UIH
3.5: Build Initial Data Collection Script for Internal Monitoring Devices
3.5.1: Read internal monitoring data from Excel
3.5.2: Cleanse Excel data
3.5.3: Insert into Zabbix DB
3.5.4: Export to Excel and verify with UIH
Service 4: Network Performance Monitoring via Zabbix Templates & Proxy
4.1: Create and configure Zabbix templates to collect performance and status data by device group and protocol type.
4.1.1: Create SNMP-based template for network device groups (CPU Memory Disk...)
4.1.2: Create API-based template for network device groups (CPU Memory...)
4.1.3: Create Python script-based template for non-standard devices (Custom Polling)
4.2: Implement Python Scripts for Data Collection for Device Groups
4.2.1: Develop Python script to collect performance data (CPU Memory etc.)
4.2.2: Integrate Python script into Zabbix via proxy
4.2.3: Validate polling and response cycle between proxy → script → device
4.3: Stream Performance & Status Data to Elasticsearch
4.3.1: Design data schema for Performance and Status metrics in Elasticsearch
4.3.2: Implement Zabbix →  Logstash (or custom pipeline) → Elasticsearch
4.3.3: Filter only essential items (e.g. CPU Memory Interface status) for streaming
4.3.4: Create dashboards (Kibana/Grafana) to visualize live metrics
4.3.5: Monitor and tune ingestion rate and index optimization
Service 5: Automated Device Inventory Collection & Log Centralization
5.1: Design Inventory Templates for Device Groups
5.1.1: Define inventory fields (hostname IP SN model firmware etc.)
5.1.2: Create 8 templates per device group (e.g. Router Switch SDWAN...)
5.1.3: Configure item type to be collected in inventory
5.1.4: Assign templates to relevant proxies
5.2: Implement Proxy & Python Integration for Device Groups (Inventory)
5.2.1: Develop Python scripts for each device group***
5.2.2: Integrate Python scripts into Zabbix Proxy
5.2.3: Schedule polling to fetch inventory data from devices
5.2.4: Return data in JSON format for further processing
5.3: Stream Inventory Logs to ElasticSearch (Stream from zabbix or Python 5.2? FileBeat)
5.3.1: Forward inventory LOG JSON output to ElasticSearch
5.3.2: Define index pattern for device-inventory-*
5.3.3: Add tagging fields (device group timestamp template)
5.3.4: Confirm log storage and searchability
5.4: Build Dashboards in Kibana & Grafana
5.4.1: Create Kibana dashboard to search inventory logs
5.4.2: Build Grafana panel using ElasticSearch queries
5.4.3: Allow filtering by device type proxy and update status
5.4.4: Set up alerts for missing/failed inventory updates
Service 6  Automated Device Configuration Collection & version control network device
6.1: Create Python Templates for Device Config Collection for Device Groups
6.1.1: Define config collection method per device group (e.g. SSH API)
6.1.2: Create Python script templates for each group (Switch Router SDWAN etc.)
6.1.3: Standardize config format output (e.g. JSON text)
6.1.4: Define expected fields per config item (hostname IP version config block...)
6.1.5: Review templates with engineering team for approval
6.2: Schedule Task Generation from Zabbix
6.2.1: Develop Python script to run on Zabbix every X minutes
6.2.2: Fetch device config template data
6.2.3: Generate config collection task and push to Redis
6.2.4: Log task creation and template used
6.3: Proxy Service Python to Execute Config Fetch for Device Groups
6.3.1: Subscribe to Redis for config-fetch tasks
6.3.2: Execute script to poll config via SSH/API
6.3.3: Parse and validate config data
6.3.4: Send result (success/fail) and output path
6.4: Store Config Files to GitLab with Versioning
6.4.1: Push config file to GitLab repo
6.4.2: Check for diff/version change
6.4.3: Commit only if changes found
6.4.4: Store commit metadata with traceability
6.5: Update Operation Status to Zabbix
6.5.1: Update Zabbix item with config status (success fail not_change)
6.5.2: Create trigger for fail threshold
6.5.3: Visualize config collection status in dashboard
Service 7: Final Optimization Training & Handover
7.1: Performance Tuning
7.1.1: Tune Zabbix Server and Proxy configuration (Cache/Pollers)
7.1.2: Tune Database parameters for high write throughput
7.2: Optimize Backend Components
7.2.1: Optimize PostgreSQL for HA and TimescaleDB performance
7.2.2: Tune Elasticsearch cluster performance for log queries
7.2.3: Tune Redis for task queue and caching efficiency
7.3: System Validation & Functional Testing
7.3.1: High Availability Failover Testing
7.3.2: Test Zabbix Server Failover
7.3.3: Test PostgreSQL Cluster Failover
7.3.4: Test HAProxy / VIP Failover
7.4: Functional Integration Testing
7.4.1: Test ELK integration with Zabbix logs and items
7.4.2: Test script to fetch config from network devices and push to GitLab
7.4.3: Test Zabbix for Inventory and Status from network devices
7.4.4: Test Excel-based import of Master Data to Zabbix
7.4.5: Test device template assignment
7.4.6: Test Master Data API integration to Zabbix
7.4.7: Test automatic host creation from Master Data
7.5: Performance Stress Test
7.5.1: Load test API with K6
7.6: Deliver Training Sessions
7.6.1: Conduct online training for System Admins
7.6.2: Conduct online training for Development team
